description.text: The Caminho Português (Camino Portuguese) covers the Camino routes starting in Portugal, usually Lisbon or Porto. Short pilgrimages usually start in Tui in Spain, It is the second-most popular route, after the French route. Variants include the side-pilgrimage to Fátima, the coastal route and the Spiritual Variant.
Capital city of Portugal and the start of the Portuguese Camino
The start point for the Portuguese Camino@en
notes: You can obtain a pilgrim's credential from inside the cathedral.@en

description.text: The headquarters of the Knights Templar before their dissolution, built according to the latest 12th century standards.@en
A Manueline-style, monastery with multiple cloisters.@en
notes: The Order of Christ was formed from the disbanded Knights Templar after King Denis I of Portugal listened to the charges against them and said, "well, I can't see it, myself.". The octagonal monastery chapel is the repurposed Templar chapel from the nearby castle.

description.text: The remains of a Roman villa from the 6th century CE@en
notes: The site is fenced. Visitors can access the site via the museum at Rua da Igreja, Rabaçal@en

description.text: A rest point for pilgrims, run by volunteers.@en
Coímbra is a city in central Portugal. It is the home of the oldest Academic instituion in the Portuguese-speaking world.@en
A national monument. The Baroque library, part of the University of Coímbra, is considered to be one of the most beautiful libraries in the world.@en
notes: The books are protected from insects by a colony of bats that live in the library. Every night, the reading tables are covered and the bats come out.@en
The library is a popular tourist destination. Entry is by time-slot and is ticketed.@en

pois.name: Jardim Botânico da Universidade de Coimbra@pt

description.text: Albergaria-a-Velha, as the name suggests, was established by Queen Teresa to provide an albergue for pilgrims.@en

description.text: There are numerous port warehouses or caves, where port is matured. Many warehouses offer tours.@en
Porto is the second largest city in Portugal. The historic centre of Porto is a UNESCO World Heritage site.@en
notes: Porto is a popular start point for those not doing the full Lisbon-Santaigo pilgrimage. Pilgrim's credencials can be obtained from the Cathedral, the tourist office and some albergues.@en

notes.text: The bookshop receives about 3000 visitors a day. Entry is by ticket, which can be obtained from the link above.

notes: Tui is a popular start point for pilgrims wanting to do the 100km to Santiago de Compostella. You can get a credential from either the catherdral or the pilgrim albergue.@en

routes.name: Caminho Português
routes.description: The main Camino route starting in Lisbon and following the inland route

routes.name: Fátima - Tomar
routes.description: A variant pilgrimage including the Fátima shrine and returning to the main route at Tomar

routes.name: Fátima - Ansião
routes.description: A variant pilgrimage including the Fátima shrine and returning to the main route near Ansião

routes.name: Variante Espiritual
routes.description: The Spiritual Variant of the main route that follows the last part of the journey of the remains of the Apostle St.James. The variant ends with a boat trip up the Río Ulla

routes.name: Coastal Route
routes.description: An alternative to the central route from Porto, the coastal route follows the Atlantic coast from Porto into Spain

routes.name: Littoral Route
routes.description: A variation on the coastal route that follows the coastline from Porto to Vila do Conde

routes.name: Coastal - Central (Vila do Conde)
routes.description: A transfer from the coastal route to the central route from Vila do Conde to São Pedro do Rates.

routes.name: Central - Coastal (São Pedro de Rates - Fão)
routes.description: A transfer from the central route to the coastal route from São Pedro de Rates to Fão.

routes.name: Coastal - Central (Minho)
routes.description: A transfer from the coastal route to the central route from Carminha to Valença do Minho, traveling along the Minho river bordering Portugal and Spain.

routes.name: Coastal - Central (Minho by Boat)
routes.description: A transfer from the coastal route to the central route from Carminha to Valença do Minho, Via Camino by Boat along the Minho river
